#Text=William Craven ( Lord Mayor of London )
#Text=Sir William Craven ( by Marcus Gheeraerts the Younger )
#Text=Sir William Craven ( 1548 – 18 July 1618 ) was an English merchant , Lord Mayor of London in 1610 ( some sources say also in 1618 [ 1 ] ) .
#Text=It has been noted that the story of Dick Whittington has some similarities to Craven 's career , though the story was first published before Craven became Lord Mayor . [ 2 ] [ 3 ]
#Text=Life

#Text=He was the second son of William Craven and Beatrix , daughter of John Hunter , and grandson of John Craven , was born at Appletreewick , a village in the parish of Burnsall , near Skipton in the West Riding of Yorkshire , about 1548 .
#Text=The date is made probable by the fact that he took up his freedom in 1569 .
#Text=At the age of thirteen or fourteen he was sent down to London by the common carrier and bound apprentice to Robert Hulson , merchant taylor , who lived in Watling Street .
#Text=Having been admitted to the freedom of the Merchant Taylors ' Company
#Text=on 4 November 1569 , Craven appears entered into business with Hulson , and subsequently quarrelled with him , with an arbitrated settlement in 1583 .
#Text=In 1588 Craven took a lease from the Mercers ' Company of a mansion house in Watling Street , where he carried on business with Robert and John Parker until his death .
#Text=He was elected warden of his company on 4 July 1593 , and on 19 July 1594 he was made one of the court of assistants .
#Text=On 2 April 1600 he was elected alderman for Bishopsgate ward , and on 14 February 1601 he was chosen sheriff of London .
#Text=On 15 May 1602 he became alderman of Cordwainer ward .
#Text=He was knighted at Whitehall by James I on 26 July 1603 .
#Text=Craven was lord mayor of London for 1610 – 11 , and the show , which had been suspended for some years , was revived with splendour .
#Text=Christian , Prince of Anhalt , was entertained with his entourage at the feast at the Guildhall afterwards .

#Text=On 14 January 1612 Craven became alderman of Lime Street ward ; he had moved his residence from St. Antholin 's to a house built by Stephen Kirton , in the parish of St. Andrew Undershaft , Cornhill .
#Text=This house was on the south side of Leadenhall Street ; it was leased to the East India Company in 1620 and pulled down , and the East India House erected in 1726 .
#Text=During Craven 's mayoralty his name appears in connection with loans to the king .

#Text=In 1616 Lady Elizabeth Coke , wife of Sir Edward Coke , on occasion of her quarrel with her husband , was at his request handed over to the hospitality of Craven , who must have entertained her at his house in Leadenhall Street .
#Text=The last public act recorded of Craven is the laying of the foundation-stone of the new Aldgate on 26 May 1618 .
#Text=On 1 July 1618 he attended the court of the Merchant Taylors ' Company for the last time .
#Text=He was buried at St. Andrew Undershaft on 11 August 1618 .
#Text=Family
#Text=He married Elizabeth Whitmore , probably about 1605 ; she was a daughter of William Whitmore ( d.1593 ) of Apley Hall , Salop and Balmes Manor , Hackney , haberdasher and alderman of London .
#Text=Her second brother was Sir George Whitmore ( d.1654 ) , Lord Mayor of London .
#Text=They had five children : Elizabeth , Mary , William ( Baron Craven of Hampstead Marshall , Berkshire and 1st Earl of Craven ) , John ( Baron Craven of Ryton ) and Thomas . [ 1 ]
#Text=In 1622 his eldest surviving daughter Elizabeth married Percy Herbert , 2nd Baron Powis .
#Text=Her sister Mary married Thomas Coventry , 2nd Baron Coventry .
#Text=His will was openly read in court on 29 July 1618 .
#Text=The second son , John Craven , founder of the Craven scholarships at Oxford and Cambridge , was commoner of Trinity College , Oxford , 1626 – 8 .
#Text=Charles I created him Baron Craven of Ryton , Shropshire , 21 March 1643 .
#Text=He died in 1649 , and left no issue by his wife , Elizabeth , daughter of William Spencer , 2nd Baron Spencer of Wormleighton and Lady Penelope Wriothesley .
#Text=Legacy
#Text=In 1596 he made a donation towards the building of the library of St John 's College , Oxford , recorded on one of the library windows .
#Text=He founded the grammar school in Burnsall , North Yorkshire , in 1602 ; this building has been in use as a school ever since then and now houses Burnsall V. A. Primary School .
#Text=The inscription " William Craven Alderman of London founder of this Schoole Anno Domini 1601 " can still be seen on a panel above the school door . [ 4 ]
#Text=In 1604 he was one of the patrons of ‘ the scheme of a new college after the manner of a university designed at Ripon , Yorkshire ’ .
#Text=On 9 January 1611 he was elected president of Christ 's Hospital , a post he occupied up to his death .
#Text=His donations to the hospital included lands to the value of £1,000 at Ugley in Essex .

#Text=On 2 July 1613 he conveyed to St John 's College the advowson of Creeke in Northamptonshire ‘ upon trust that one of the ten senior fellows elected from ( Merchant Taylors ' ) School should be presented thereto ’ .
#Text=In 1617 he joined with others in subscribing £1,000 towards the repair and decoration of St. Antholin 's Church .

#Text=By John Craven 's will , dated 18 May 1647 , he left large charitable bequests to Burnsall , Skipton , Ripon , Ripley , Knaresborough , and Boroughbridge , and money for redeeming captives in Algiers .

#Text=His most important legacy was that of the manor of Cancerne , near Chichester , Sussex , to provide £100 for four poor scholars , two at Cambridge and two at Oxford , with preference to his own poor kinsmen .
#Text=The first award under the bequest was made at Cambridge 16 May 1649 .
#Text=The fund was immediately afterwards sequestrated by parliament , and on 7 May 1651 a petition was presented for the payment of the scholarships .
#Text=In 1654 the sequestration was discharged .
#Text=The bequest was maintained at both universities .
